Situation1: Their partner had a mildly stressful day at work and mentions it casually.
Expectation2: Wash and condition clients' hair before cutting or styling
Situation2: Heavy product buildup is causing tight tangles that will impede scissors.
Story: I glanced at the clock, knowing my last client of the day would arrive any minute. My phone buzzed with a message from my husband: “Rough day. Just want to talk when you’re home.” I could picture him, slumped on the couch, needing me to listen, to reassure him, to be present. But as my client settled into the chair, I ran my fingers through her hair and felt the thick, sticky buildup. The tangles were tight, stubborn, and I knew I’d need extra time to wash and condition before I could even think about cutting. She expected me to work my magic, to make her hair feel light and fresh again. My mind tugged in two directions—my husband’s quiet plea for comfort, and the client’s unspoken hope for transformation. I felt the weight of both roles pressing on me, the urge to be a caring wife and a dedicated hairdresser, each demanding my full attention. My heart raced as I tried to figure out how to be enough for both, knowing I couldn’t give all of myself to either at the same time.
